clusters.title: Ousted Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for student protest crackdown
clusters.neutral_headline: Ousted Bangladesh Prime Minister Sentenced to Death

items.title: Ousted Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for student protest crackdown
items.standfirst: Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh's ousted prime minister, has been sentenced to death by a special tribunal on charges of crimes against humanity over the killing of hundreds of people during a student-led uprising in July and August of 2024. BBC correspondent Arunoday Mukharji joins CBS News with more.
items.content: Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh's ousted prime minister, has been sentenced to death by a special tribunal on charges of crimes against humanity over the killing of hundreds of people during a student-led uprising in July and August of 2024. BBC correspondent Arunoday Mukharji joins CBS News with more.

items.title: Ousted Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for crimes against humanity
items.standfirst: Hasina sentenced in absentia by court in Dhaka over deadly crackdown on student-led uprising last yearBangladesh’s deposed prime minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death in absentia by a court in Dhaka for crimes against humanity over a deadly crackdown on a student-led uprising last year.A three-judge bench of the country’s international crimes tribunal convicted Hasina of crimes including incitement, orders to kill and inaction to prevent atrocities as she oversaw a crackdown on anti-government protesters last year. Continue reading...
items.content: Hasina sentenced in absentia by court in Dhaka over deadly crackdown on student-led uprising last yearBangladesh’s deposed prime minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death in absentia by a court in Dhaka for crimes against humanity over a deadly crackdown on a student-led uprising last year.A three-judge bench of the country’s international crimes tribunal convicted Hasina of crimes including incitement, orders to kill and inaction to prevent atrocities as she oversaw a crackdown on anti-government protesters last year. Continue reading...

items.title: Exiled Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death in absentia
items.standfirst: A Bangladeshi tribunal has sentenced former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to death for crimes against humanity.
items.content: A Bangladeshi tribunal has sentenced former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to death for crimes against humanity.

items.title: Bangladesh's ousted prime minister sentenced to death for role in protest crackdown
items.standfirst: A tribunal in Dhaka sentenced Sheikh Hasina to death for her involvement in the use of deadly force against protesters last year. She fled to India and was sentenced in absentia.
items.content: A tribunal in Dhaka sentenced Sheikh Hasina to death for her involvement in the use of deadly force against protesters last year. She fled to India and was sentenced in absentia.(Image credit: Rajesh Kumar Singh)

items.title: Concerns over death sentence for former Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina
items.standfirst: A court in Bangladesh has sentenced former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to death, over a violent crackdown on protests.
items.content: A court in Bangladesh has sentenced former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to death, over a violent crackdown on protests.

items.title: Ex-Bangladesh leader Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for students crackdown
items.standfirst: A court in Bangladesh on Monday sentenced ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina to death for ordering a deadly crackdown on student-led protests last year. Hasina, who was sentenced in absentia after fleeing to India, was found guilty of crimes against humanity. Solange Mougin reports.
items.content: A court in Bangladesh on Monday sentenced ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina to death for ordering a deadly crackdown on student-led protests last year. Hasina, who was sentenced in absentia after fleeing to India, was found guilty of crimes against humanity. Solange Mougin reports.

items.title: Cheers in Bangladesh court as former PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death
items.standfirst: There were cheers in court as Bangladesh’s International Crimes Tribunal sentenced Sheikh Hasina to death.
items.content: There were cheers in court as Bangladesh’s International Crimes Tribunal sentenced Sheikh Hasina to death.

items.title: Ousted Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death
items.standfirst: Former Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death over a deadly crackdown on anti-government protests last year.
items.content: Former Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death over a deadly crackdown on anti-government protests last year.

items.title: Moment Ex-Bangladesh leader Sheikh Hasina's sentence is announced
items.standfirst: Hasina has called the court's decision "biased and politically motivated" in a statement released after the verdict.
items.content: Hasina has called the court's decision "biased and politically motivated" in a statement released after the verdict.

items.title: Bangladesh sentences former prime minister Sheikh Hasina to death
items.standfirst: Ex-leader was tried in absentia after fleeing to India in wake of popular uprising
items.content: Ex-leader was tried in absentia after fleeing to India in wake of popular uprising

items.title: Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death after lethal crackdown on uprising
items.standfirst: Bangladesh's ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death.
items.content: Bangladesh's ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death.

ai_summary: A Bangladesh tribunal sentenced former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to death in absentia.
The sentence is for crimes against humanity related to a student protest crackdown.
Hasina fled to India and was sentenced by the court in Dhaka.
The court convicted Hasina of incitement and inaction during the crackdown.
Concerns have been raised regarding the death sentence for the former leader.

clusters.title: Trump is ‘panicking’ after failing ‘to kill our Jeffrey Epstein investigation’, says top Democrat, after president’s sudden pivot – live
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump's stance on Epstein files shifts, calls for release

items.title: Trump is ‘panicking’ after failing ‘to kill our Jeffrey Epstein investigation’, says top Democrat, after president’s sudden pivot – live
items.standfirst: Robert Garcia, ranking member of House oversight committee, says president has ‘realized he is about to lose this Epstein vote’ and calls for release of filesTrump urges Republicans to vote for release of Epstein files in surprise U-turnUS Border Patrol officials said they had arrested 81 people over five hours in Charlotte, North Carolina, on Saturday, the first day of the targeted operation. The crackdown involving federal agents was only announced last week.Mass deportation and strict enforcement of immigration laws have been a key part of Trump’s agenda since returning to office this year. Continue reading...

The crackdown involving federal agents was only announced last week.Mass deportation and strict enforcement of immigration laws have been a key part of Trump’s agenda since returning to office this year. items.title: Latest on Epstein files as Trump changes course and calls for release
items.standfirst: President Trump is now calling on the House GOP to vote in favor of releasing the Jeffrey Epstein files. CBS News' Natalie Brand and Nikole Killion have more.
items.content: President Trump is now calling on the House GOP to vote in favor of releasing the Jeffrey Epstein files. CBS News' Natalie Brand and Nikole Killion have more.

items.title: Trump slams Marjorie Taylor Greene and Democrats over Epstein files
items.standfirst: President Trump reversed course, calling for the release of all files relating to Jeffrey Epstein amid ongoing controversy in the House over a forced vote. Meanwhile, Mr. Trump slammed GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene over her changing views. CBS News' Olivia Rinaldi and Taurean Small have the latest.
items.content: President Trump reversed course, calling for the release of all files relating to Jeffrey Epstein amid ongoing controversy in the House over a forced vote. Meanwhile, Mr. Trump slammed GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene over her changing views. CBS News' Olivia Rinaldi and Taurean Small have the latest.

items.title: In major reversal, Trump says he supports the release of Epstein files
items.standfirst: In a social media post on Sunday, President Trump urged House Republicans to vote to release the files related to Jeffrey Epstein after months of strong opposition. The House is expected to vote Tuesday on a bill that would force the DOJ to release the files.
items.content: In a social media post on Sunday, President Trump urged House Republicans to vote to release the files related to Jeffrey Epstein after months of strong opposition. The House is expected to vote Tuesday on a bill that would force the DOJ to release the files.

items.title: Trump says nobody cares about "traitor" Marjorie Taylor Greene as feud escalates
items.standfirst: President Trump told reporters that he doesn't think "anybody cares about" Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene after he withdrew support for the Georgia Republican, and as both remain at odds over the Epstein files, the government shutdown and the future of health care costs. CBS News' Taurean Small has more.
items.content: President Trump told reporters that he doesn't think "anybody cares about" Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene after he withdrew support for the Georgia Republican, and as both remain at odds over the Epstein files, the government shutdown and the future of health care costs. CBS News' Taurean Small has more.

items.title: Trump blames Democrats for using Epstein files as a deflection
items.standfirst: President Trump changed his tone over files related to Jeffrey Epstein, calling for a full release while saying the Democrats have used the matter as a deflection. CBS News' Olivia Rinaldi has the latest.
items.content: President Trump changed his tone over files related to Jeffrey Epstein, calling for a full release while saying the Democrats have used the matter as a deflection. CBS News' Olivia Rinaldi has the latest.

items.title: Trump urges Republicans to vote for release of Epstein files in surprise U-turn
items.standfirst: US president says he backs efforts to release documents related to late sex offender because ‘we have nothing to hide’US politics live – latest updatesHow the Epstein row plunged Maga world into turmoil – a timelineEpstein emails: key takeaways from 20,000 pages of newly released filesA top Democrat has accused Donald Trump of “panicking” after the US president told his fellow Republicans in Congress to vote for the release of files related to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, in a sudden reversal of his earlier position.Robert Garcia, the ranking member on of the House oversight committee, which released a tranche of new Epstein documents last week, said that Trump “has tried everything to kill our Jeffrey Epstein investigation”. Continue reading...
items.content: US president says he backs efforts to release documents related to late sex offender because ‘we have nothing to hide’US politics live – latest updatesHow the Epstein row plunged Maga world into turmoil – a timelineEpstein emails: key takeaways from 20,000 pages of newly released filesA top Democrat has accused Donald Trump of “panicking” after the US president told his fellow Republicans in Congress to vote for the release of files related to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, in a sudden reversal of his earlier position.Robert Garcia, the ranking member on of the House oversight committee, which released a tranche of new Epstein documents last week, said that Trump “has tried everything to kill our Jeffrey Epstein investigation”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump urges House Republicans to vote for release of Epstein files
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Sunday backed Republican lawmakers’ efforts to release more files on sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, despite previously opposing the move. But this change of heart does not mean the documents will be public soon, or even ever. France24 Charli James walks us through the different political paths for Congress and Trump.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Sunday backed Republican lawmakers’ efforts to release more files on sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, despite previously opposing the move. But this change of heart does not mean the documents will be public soon, or even ever. France24 Charli James walks us through the different political paths for Congress and Trump.

items.title: Trump’s reversal with call to release Epstein files reveals inability to control Maga allies
items.standfirst: President attempts to save face politically after pressuring Republicans to back off their pushes to release filesUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump’s call for Republicans to back the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files, an abrupt reversal, is a rare instance of the president being unable to tame his Maga base and being instead forced to accede to it.Many Republicans are expected to support a vote in the US House this week to force the justice department to release the files. Once the measure passes, it would still need approval in the US Senate, where 13 Republican senators would need to join with all 47 Democrats to approve it. Continue reading...
items.content: President attempts to save face politically after pressuring Republicans to back off their pushes to release filesUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump’s call for Republicans to back the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files, an abrupt reversal, is a rare instance of the president being unable to tame his Maga base and being instead forced to accede to it.Many Republicans are expected to support a vote in the US House this week to force the justice department to release the files. Once the measure passes, it would still need approval in the US Senate, where 13 Republican senators would need to join with all 47 Democrats to approve it. Continue reading...

But this change of heart does not mean the documents will be public soon, or even ever. France24 Charli James walks us through the different political paths for Congress and Trump.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Sunday backed Republican lawmakers’ efforts to release more files on sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, despite previously opposing the move. But this change of heart does not mean the documents will be public soon, or even ever. France24 Charli James walks us through the different political paths for Congress and Trump.

items.content: "We have nothing to hide," the US president writes - a reversal after previously resisting publishing the documents.

items.title: Trump changes stance on Epstein files. And, the U.S. increases pressure on Venezuela
items.standfirst: President Trump changes stance on the Epstein files, urging Republicans to support a House vote tomorrow. And, the U.S. military buildup in the Caribbean adds pressure on Venezuela.

clusters.title: Polish PM says railway explosion was 'unprecedented act of sabotage'
clusters.neutral_headline: Polish PM Says Railway Explosion Was Sabotage

items.title: Polish PM says railway explosion was 'unprecedented act of sabotage'
items.standfirst: Authorities say the blast happened on a line leading to the border with Ukraine.
items.content: Authorities say the blast happened on a line leading to the border with Ukraine.

items.title: Poland railway blast was unprecedented act of sabotage, says Donald Tusk
items.standfirst: Polish PM vows to ‘catch the perpetrators, regardless of who their backers are’ after blast on track used for deliveries to UkrainePoland’s prime minister, Donald Tusk, has described an explosion along a section of railway line used for deliveries to Ukraine as an “unprecedented act of sabotage” that could have led to disaster.It came as a statement from public prosecutors on Monday evening said an investigation had opened “regarding acts of sabotage of a terrorist nature […] committed on behalf of a foreign intelligence service against the Republic of Poland.” Continue reading...
items.content: Polish PM vows to ‘catch the perpetrators, regardless of who their backers are’ after blast on track used for deliveries to UkrainePoland’s prime minister, Donald Tusk, has described an explosion along a section of railway line used for deliveries to Ukraine as an “unprecedented act of sabotage” that could have led to disaster.It came as a statement from public prosecutors on Monday evening said an investigation had opened “regarding acts of sabotage of a terrorist nature […] committed on behalf of a foreign intelligence service against the Republic of Poland.” Continue reading...

items.title: Foreign state services behind Polish rail sabotage, says minister – as it happened
items.standfirst: Security services minister Tomasz Siemoniak says explosion was not the work of ‘a gang of metal thieves’. This live blog is closedBack to Poland, the country’s interior minister is hosting an emergency meeting on the train incidents, with transport, justice ministers, police and representatives of security services all attending.“Poland is facing acts of sabotage unprecedented in its most recent history,” Marcin Kierwiński said in a social media post. Continue reading...
items.content: Security services minister Tomasz Siemoniak says explosion was not the work of ‘a gang of metal thieves’. This live blog is closedBack to Poland, the country’s interior minister is hosting an emergency meeting on the train incidents, with transport, justice ministers, police and representatives of security services all attending.“Poland is facing acts of sabotage unprecedented in its most recent history,” Marcin Kierwiński said in a social media post. Continue reading...

items.title: Polish PM denounces ‘sabotage’ after explosion hits railway line to Ukraine
items.standfirst: Poland’s Prime Minister Donald Tusk has condemned an explosion that damaged a key rail line to Ukraine as an “unprecedented act of sabotage” on Monday, saying it may have been ordered by foreign intelligence. The blast, likely meant to derail a train, has triggered a major investigation.
items.content: Poland’s Prime Minister Donald Tusk has condemned an explosion that damaged a key rail line to Ukraine as an “unprecedented act of sabotage” on Monday, saying it may have been ordered by foreign intelligence. The blast, likely meant to derail a train, has triggered a major investigation.

items.title: Railway bombing an 'unprecedented act of sabotage', Polish PM says
items.standfirst: An explosion on a key Polish railway line used to transport weapons to Ukraine was caused by an "unprecedented act of sabotage", according to the country's prime minister.
items.content: An explosion on a key Polish railway line used to transport weapons to Ukraine was caused by an "unprecedented act of sabotage", according to the country's prime minister.

ai_summary: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk called the railway explosion an act of sabotage.
The explosion occurred on a railway line used to transport goods to Ukraine.
Polish authorities are investigating the explosion, which could have caused disaster.
The government is investigating the possibility of foreign intelligence involvement.
The incident is considered unprecedented in recent Polish history.

clusters.title: ‘Historic agreement’: Ukraine to receive fleet of French fighter jets
clusters.neutral_headline: Ukraine to Acquire French Fighter Jets

items.title: ‘Historic agreement’: Ukraine to receive fleet of French fighter jets
items.standfirst: France and Ukraine have signed a declaration of intent for Kyiv to acquire up to 100 Rafale fighter jets.
items.content: France and Ukraine have signed a declaration of intent for Kyiv to acquire up to 100 Rafale fighter jets.

items.title: Macron and Zelensky sign a letter of intent for Ukraine to purchase up to 100 Rafale fighter jets
items.standfirst: France's President Emmanuel Macron and Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky signed on Monday an accord for Kyiv to acquire up to 100 Rafale fighter jets and other hardware, a boost for Ukraine's war effort. Elitsa Gadeva gives us the details on what exactly the deal entails .
items.content: France's President Emmanuel Macron and Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky signed on Monday an accord for Kyiv to acquire up to 100 Rafale fighter jets and other hardware, a boost for Ukraine's war effort. Elitsa Gadeva gives us the details on what exactly the deal entails .

items.title: Macron and Zelensky sign letter of intent for Ukraine to buy Rafale fighter jets
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his French counterpart Emmanuel Macron signed a letter of intent on Monday for Kyiv to acquire up to 100 Rafale warplanes and new air-defence systems to strengthen its long-term war effort. Zelensky's visit to Paris comes as Russian drone and missile strikes intensify and Moscow claims frontline gains. France24 journalist Antonia Kerrigan reports the latest.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his French counterpart Emmanuel Macron signed a letter of intent on Monday for Kyiv to acquire up to 100 Rafale warplanes and new air-defence systems to strengthen its long-term war effort. Zelensky's visit to Paris comes as Russian drone and missile strikes intensify and Moscow claims frontline gains. France24 journalist Antonia Kerrigan reports the latest.

items.title: Macron hosts Ukrainian leader Zelensky at the Elysée Palace
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky at the Elysée Palace for a press conference, after both leaders signed a major deal for Ukraine to acquire French military equipment, including Rafale fighter jets, France's flagship combat aircraft. The Director at OPEWI Europe’s War Institute, Michael Benhamou, shares his insights.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky at the Elysée Palace for a press conference, after both leaders signed a major deal for Ukraine to acquire French military equipment, including Rafale fighter jets, France's flagship combat aircraft. The Director at OPEWI Europe’s War Institute, Michael Benhamou, shares his insights.

items.title: REPLAY: Macron and Zelensky discuss Rafale fighter jet deal at joint briefing
items.standfirst: France's President Emmanuel Macron and Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky Monday signed a letter of intent for Kyiv to acquire up to 100 Rafale fighter jets and other military hardware, a boost for Ukraine as it fights the Russian invasion. Watch their joint press conference at the Élysée presidential palace.
items.content: France's President Emmanuel Macron and Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky Monday signed a letter of intent for Kyiv to acquire up to 100 Rafale fighter jets and other military hardware, a boost for Ukraine as it fights the Russian invasion. Watch their joint press conference at the Élysée presidential palace.

items.title: Ukraine to buy 100 fighter jets from France in bid to create 'one of the greatest' air defences in the world
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has signed a letter of intent with France to obtain 100 Rafale fighter jets as he seeks to bolster the country's long-term air defence capacity against Russia.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has signed a letter of intent with France to obtain 100 Rafale fighter jets as he seeks to bolster the country's long-term air defence capacity against Russia.

ai_summary: France and Ukraine signed a deal for Ukraine to buy up to 100 Rafale fighter jets.
The deal includes other military hardware to support Ukraine's war effort.
The agreement was signed during a visit by Zelensky to Paris.
The deal aims to strengthen Ukraine's long-term defense capabilities.
The announcement comes amid intensified Russian attacks on Ukraine.

clusters.title: USS Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier arrives in Caribbean as U.S. ramps up military presence

items.title: USS Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier arrives in Caribbean as U.S. ramps up military presence
items.standfirst: The USS Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier arrived in the Caribbean on Sunday as the U.S. ramps up its presence in the region and weighs action against Venezuela. Former national intelligence officer Fulton Armstrong has more.
items.content: The USS Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier arrived in the Caribbean on Sunday as the U.S. ramps up its presence in the region and weighs action against Venezuela. Former national intelligence officer Fulton Armstrong has more.

items.title: Most advanced US aircraft carrier arrives close to Venezuela amid military build-up
items.standfirst: The most advanced US aircraft carrier has travelled to the Caribbean Sea in what has been interpreted as a show of military power and a possible threat to Venezuela's Nicolas Maduro regime.
items.content: The most advanced US aircraft carrier has travelled to the Caribbean Sea in what has been interpreted as a show of military power and a possible threat to Venezuela's Nicolas Maduro regime.

items.title: U.S. intensifies military pressure on Venezuela as Trump considers talks with Maduro
items.standfirst: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump said Sunday he may hold talks with Venezuela's Nicolás Maduro, even as the United States intensified its military pressure with the latest strike on an alleged drug boat and the arrival of its most advanced aircraft carrier
items.content: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump said Sunday he may hold talks with Venezuela's Nicolás Maduro, even as the United States intensified its military pressure with the latest strike on an alleged drug boat and the arrival of its most advanced aircraft carrier

The move is interpreted as a show of force near Venezuela.
The US is considering action against the Maduro regime.
Trump has said he may hold talks with Venezuela's Maduro.

items.title: France probes Vinted over alleged exposure of minors to adult content
items.standfirst: France’s child protection chief has called for an investigation into second-hand platform Vinted on Monday, after ads were found redirecting users – including minors – to pornographic sites, marking the latest move in a widening crackdown on global e-commerce giants.

clusters.title: New blow for Louvre as structural problem forces gallery closure
clusters.neutral_headline: Louvre Gallery Closed Due to Structural Issues

items.title: New blow for Louvre as structural problem forces gallery closure
items.standfirst: Campana Gallery is temporarily shut due to weaknesses in beams supporting floor above The Louvre has temporarily closed one of its galleries as a precaution after an audit revealed structural weaknesses in some of the beams in the building.The Campana Gallery, which houses nine rooms dedicated to ancient Greek ceramics, will be shut while investigations are conducted into “certain beams supporting the floors of the second floor” above it, a statement issued on Monday said. Continue reading...
items.content: Campana Gallery is temporarily shut due to weaknesses in beams supporting floor above The Louvre has temporarily closed one of its galleries as a precaution after an audit revealed structural weaknesses in some of the beams in the building.The Campana Gallery, which houses nine rooms dedicated to ancient Greek ceramics, will be shut while investigations are conducted into “certain beams supporting the floors of the second floor” above it, a statement issued on Monday said. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: The Campana Gallery, which host Greek ceramics, will remain closed as beams supporting the floor above are checked.
items.content: The Campana Gallery, which host Greek ceramics, will remain closed as beams supporting the floor above are checked.

items.title: Louvre closes Greek ceramics gallery over structural safety concerns
items.standfirst: France’s most famous museum, The Louvre, has temporarily closed its Campana Gallery on Monday, after an audit uncovered structural weaknesses in beams supporting the floor above, prompting safety concerns. This comes as the embattled museum is already under scrutiny following last month’s $102 million jewellery heist.
items.content: France’s most famous museum, The Louvre, has temporarily closed its Campana Gallery on Monday, after an audit uncovered structural weaknesses in beams supporting the floor above, prompting safety concerns. This comes as the embattled museum is already under scrutiny following last month’s $102 million jewellery heist.

ai_summary: The Louvre has temporarily closed the Campana Gallery.
The closure is due to structural weaknesses in the beams.
The gallery houses ancient Greek ceramics.
An audit revealed weaknesses in the beams supporting the floor.
The closure is a precautionary measure.

clusters.title: Chile heads to a presidential run-off between Jara and Kast
clusters.neutral_headline: Chile Heads to Presidential Run-Off

items.title: Chile heads to a presidential run-off between Jara and Kast
items.standfirst: Left-wing presidential candidate Jeanette Jara is leading in the first round of Chile’s presidential election, according to provisional results, and is now expected to face far-right contender José Antonio Kast in the December 14 runoff. The vote is considered one of the most polarized in recent years, shaped largely by debates over immigration and a sharp rise in murders, kidnappings, and extortion over the past decade, often attributed to foreign gangs. Charlotte Hughes has the latest.
items.content: Left-wing presidential candidate Jeanette Jara is leading in the first round of Chile’s presidential election, according to provisional results, and is now expected to face far-right contender José Antonio Kast in the December 14 runoff. The vote is considered one of the most polarized in recent years, shaped largely by debates over immigration and a sharp rise in murders, kidnappings, and extortion over the past decade, often attributed to foreign gangs. Charlotte Hughes has the latest.

items.title: Communist and far-right candidates head to Chile presidential run-off
items.standfirst: The Communist Party's Jeanette Jara will face far-right candidate José Antonio Kast in the second round of voting in December.
items.content: The Communist Party's Jeanette Jara will face far-right candidate José Antonio Kast in the second round of voting in December.

items.title: Far-right candidate José Antonio Kast favourite to become Chile’s next president after first round vote
items.standfirst: The ultraconservative lawyer is in pole position going into the second round election, after running a campaign with a distinctly Trumpian feel​The ultraconservative lawyer, José Antonio Kast, is in pole position to become Chile’s next leader after advancing to the second round of the South American country’s presidential election where he will face the Communist party candidate Jeannette Jara.With more than 70% of votes counted, Kast had secured about 24% of the vote in Sunday’s first round vote, having campaigned on hard-line promises to crack down on crime and immigration, while making a Donald Trump-style pledge to “put Chileans first”. Continue reading...
items.content: The ultraconservative lawyer is in pole position going into the second round election, after running a campaign with a distinctly Trumpian feel​The ultraconservative lawyer, José Antonio Kast, is in pole position to become Chile’s next leader after advancing to the second round of the South American country’s presidential election where he will face the Communist party candidate Jeannette Jara.With more than 70% of votes counted, Kast had secured about 24% of the vote in Sunday’s first round vote, having campaigned on hard-line promises to crack down on crime and immigration, while making a Donald Trump-style pledge to “put Chileans first”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Jeanette Jara and José Antonio Kast will face off in Chile's run-off.
Jara is the left-wing candidate, Kast is far-right.
The election is considered highly polarized.
The election is shaped by debates over immigration and crime.
Kast is favored to win the election.

items.title: Reselling tickets for profit to be outlawed in UK government crackdown
items.standfirst: Touts – and ordinary consumers – will no longer be able to charge anything more than price at which they purchased ticket Reselling tickets for profit is to be outlawed under plans due to be announced this week, the Guardian has learned, as the government goes ahead with a long-awaited crackdown…
items.content: Touts – and ordinary consumers – will no longer be able to charge anything more than price at which they purchased ticket Reselling tickets for profit is to be outlawed under plans due to be announced this week, the Guardian has learned, as the government goes ahead with a long-awaited crackdown…

items.title: Reselling tickets for profit to be outlawed in UK government crackdown
items.standfirst: Touts, and ordinary consumers, will no longer be able to charge anything more than price at which they bought ticketReselling tickets for profit is to be outlawed under plans due to be announced this week, the Guardian has learned, as the government goes ahead with a long-awaited crackdown on touts and resale platforms such as Viagogo and StubHub.Ministers had been considering allowing touts – and ordinary consumers – to sell on a ticket for up to 30% above the original face value, as part of a consultation process that ended earlier this year. Continue reading...
items.content: Touts, and ordinary consumers, will no longer be able to charge anything more than price at which they bought ticketReselling tickets for profit is to be outlawed under plans due to be announced this week, the Guardian has learned, as the government goes ahead with a long-awaited crackdown on touts and resale platforms such as Viagogo and StubHub.Ministers had been considering allowing touts – and ordinary consumers – to sell on a ticket for up to 30% above the original face value, as part of a consultation process that ended earlier this year. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The UK government plans to outlaw reselling tickets for profit.
The ban will affect touts and ordinary consumers alike.
Ticket sellers will only be able to charge the original price.
The government is cracking down on resale platforms.
Ministers considered allowing a 30% markup on ticket sales.

clusters.title: Two long-lost organ pieces by JS Bach performed for first time in 300 years
clusters.neutral_headline: Bach's Long-Lost Organ Pieces Performed

items.title: Two long-lost organ pieces by JS Bach performed for first time in 300 years
items.standfirst: Archive director in Germany says ‘missing piece of puzzle’ now in place to verify authorship after decades of researchTwo long-lost organ pieces by Johann Sebastian Bach have been performed in Germany, roughly 320 years after the composer wrote them as a teenage music teacher.Entitled Chaconne in D minor BWV 1178 and Chaconne in G minor BWV 1179, the pieces were added to the official catalogue of Bach’s works on Monday and played in public for the first time in three centuries inside Leipzig’s St Thomas Church, where Bach is buried. Continue reading...
items.content: Archive director in Germany says ‘missing piece of puzzle’ now in place to verify authorship after decades of researchTwo long-lost organ pieces by Johann Sebastian Bach have been performed in Germany, roughly 320 years after the composer wrote them as a teenage music teacher.Entitled Chaconne in D minor BWV 1178 and Chaconne in G minor BWV 1179, the pieces were added to the official catalogue of Bach’s works on Monday and played in public for the first time in three centuries inside Leipzig’s St Thomas Church, where Bach is buried. Continue reading...

items.title: 'Guess who's Bach?': Two long-lost organ works by Bach unveiled in Germany
items.standfirst: Two previously unknown organ pieces by a teenage Johann Sebastian Bach were unveiled Monday in Leipzig and performed for the first time in over 300 years. Long-mysterious manuscripts have now been confirmed as Bach's works, adding new repertoire and insight into the composer's early genius.
items.content: Two previously unknown organ pieces by a teenage Johann Sebastian Bach were unveiled Monday in Leipzig and performed for the first time in over 300 years. Long-mysterious manuscripts have now been confirmed as Bach's works, adding new repertoire and insight into the composer's early genius.

ai_summary: Two lost organ pieces by JS Bach were performed in Germany.
The pieces were written by Bach as a teenage music teacher.
The pieces are titled Chaconne in D minor and G minor.
They were added to the Bach catalog on Monday.
The performance occurred in Leipzig's St Thomas Church.

Wen, 26, has a history of disrupting public events and rushing concert stages. Continue reading...
